Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Movement Ecology and Hominin Behavioral Evolution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Humans have shown an extraordinary ability to live and thrive in almost every environment on the planet. Investigating past strategies that humans used to negotiate their surroundings is critical to further understanding the origins of this amazing adaptability. This dissertation project combines computer modeling and stone tool analysis to understand how our hominin ancestors interacted with their surrounding environments, providing new insights into the evolutionary significance of human-environment interactions. The co-PI will conduct K-12 and public science education outreach activities, and aspects of this project will be carried out in conjunction with a long-standing field research and training program, contributing to the training of American students from diverse backgrounds in archaeology, geology, and ecology.

Archaeology has developed a variety of analytical frameworks for documenting human-environment interactions. However, one of the main issues that researchers face is that the archaeological record is time-averaged, meaning that archaeological sites do not represent individual activities but rather an aggregation of them over long time-frames. Thus, in order to understand how past humans interacted with their environments, new methods are needed to document meaningful patterns from aggregated traces of human behavior. This project builds an analytical framework by which hypotheses regarding time-averaged patterns of past human behaviors can be generated and tested. The project combines agent-based modeling with measures of stone tool utilization and transport to characterize hominin land use through the lens of movement. This framework is then applied to time-averaged lithic assemblages to characterize human land use patterns in landscapes. These data are mapped onto raw material source and paleogeographic data to test whether documented differences in land use patterns are the result paleoenvironmental variation. Preliminary results of this work indicate that this project has great potential to provide new insights into hominin ecology and evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work examined the relationship between Early Stone Age hominins and the landscapes that they inhabited. This was done by documenting the ways in which these hominins moved across the landscape. Research has shown that the ways humans, as well as most mammals, is influenced by the environments that they live in. Therefore, understanding the relationship between hominin movements and the landscapes that they lived in can tell us a great deal about the adaptive underpinnings of the success of the human species on a global scale. More specifically, this work reconstructed Early Stone Age hominin movement patterns by documenting the ways in which hominins moved stone tools around the landscape. The relationship between the places from which hominins acquired stone tools from and where they used them, in combination with how extensively they were used provides a way to reconstruct hominin movement patterns. However, the Early Stone Age record is not equivalent to the modern hunter-gather populations and the landscapes in which they live. The Early Stone Age archaeological record is the material aggregate of human behavior over potentially thousands of years. In this sense, observations of modern hunter-gatherer populations that have traditionally provide a way for archaeologists to interpret archaeological patterns do not have the same interpretative power in the Early Stone Age. 

Thus, in reconstructing patterns of hominin land-use, this work combined traditional archaeological investigations with agent-based modeling. This provide a way to generate more interpretations of the archaeological record. The results of this project, generated a new framework in which can be used to investigate hominin behavior in the Early Stone Age. The application of this framework to archaeological data shows hominin land use patterns were influence by a combination of access to resources, and broad scale paleo-geography. As a result, this work has begun to shed light on the potential adaptive mechanisms that underlie the ecological success of the human species.
